questions.question_text: A network technician is investigating why a user cannot print to the network printer. The technician wants to determine if anything has changed. Which of the following actions would be the BEST example of this troubleshooting step?

choices.B: Log into the switch and reconfigure the printer port.
choices.C: Review the maintenance logs from the night before.
choices.D: Reinstall print drivers on the user's machine.
choices.A: Attempt to log in from another computer with the user's credentials.

discussion.content: I understand, admin is trying to see if anything has changed. But why on earth you would do that if everything, perhaps, works on other computers? I would FIRST definitely try from other computer.. so I would choose A.

comments.content: Its not that serious, we are all here to learn
So it is easier to look into logs than to log in to another computer and try if it works.. of course.. and yes. behave.
what r u smoking? the ANSWER is literally in the question "He wants to determine if anything has changed" can u not fking read?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
key word ; Voice Communication

questions.question_text: Which of the following can be used to enable and translate the communication between legacy non-IP phone systems with solutions for voice communications that can run over the Internet?

discussion.content:
Our subnet is .128 and our IP is .144:
/26 mask .192 = .144 would fall into this subnet range .128-.191
/28 mask .240 = .144 would be the network ID (16 hosts) .128-.143, .144-.160
/29 mask .248 = .144 would be the broadcast ID (8 hosts) .128-135, .136-.144
this is a class B private IP range but all the choices are for subnets for class C private IP ranges. these answers make no sense

you need to do some reverse engineering. from the answers, we see that the subnet mask are all 255.255.255.x, despite the IP address being a traditional class B. This tells us that this a classless subnetting.
using the subnet mask, 255 reps the network portion and cannot be altered, which leaves us to only focus on the last octet.
an octet reps 8bits (11111111) which equals 255 in binary. starting from the left,
128, 64, 32, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1 = 2^7 , 2^6 ,â€¦2^0
192 =128 + 64 i.e. 2bits
from the subnet 255.255.255.x, the "255" reps 24bits (network portion) while x reps host portion
192 makes up 2 bits which will be added to the network portion since it is classless subnetting (CIDR) to make 26 bits.
a typical IP address is made up of 32 bits. which means that 32 -26 = 6bits left for the host portion.
2^6 = 64
172.28.57.128 = network address (the 1st address on any subnet)
128 + 63 (not 64 as .128 is already the 1st address) = 191
therefore the range is 172.28.57.128 - .191

the other answers are subnets that do not capture .144 together with .128
C is the valid answer here.

because we know the subnet is 128. all you have to do is add 64 to find the subnet mask
Check here
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ecCuyq-Wprc
Anyone with an explanation here please?

comments.content: because the questions says on subnet 172.28.57.128 and with mask 248 there is no subnet with 128

discussion.content: Hello evryone, can you help? Why answer is not 255.255.255.248 --> /29

questions.question_text: A host has an IP address of 172.28.57.144 and is on the 172.28.57.128 subnet. Which of the following is a correct subnet mask of the host?
Which of the following relies on metrics such as total number of connections or CPU/RAM usage to help maintain performance and availability?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
key word = maintain performance and availability

questions.question_text: A network technician is running copper cable from a core switch to a network closet that is approximately 574ft (175m) away. Which of the following should the technician use to accomplish this?

discussion.content: A Bridge can also be used as a repeater. The cable is too long will have attenuation otherwise.

comments.content: over 100m in length, copper only good for 1-100m. needs a repeater to boost the signal, bridge does it
